lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: And kill him in the shell.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: The Taper burneth in your Closet, Sir:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Searching the Window for a Flint, I found

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: This Paper, thus seal'd vp, and I am sure

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: It did not lye there when I went to Bed.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Get you to Bed againe, it is not day:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Is not to morrow (Boy) the first of March?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: I know not, Sir.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Looke in the Calender, and bring me word.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: I will, Sir.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The exhalations, whizzing in the ayre,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Giue so much light, that I may reade by them.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Brutus thou sleep'st; awake, and see thy selfe:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Shall Rome, &c. speake, strike, redresse.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Such instigations haue beene often dropt,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Where I haue tooke them vp:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: {% italic: Shall Rome, &c %}. Thus must I piece it out:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Shall Rome stand vnder one mans awe? What Rome?

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: My Ancestors did from the streetes of Rome

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The {% italic: Tarquin %} driue, when he was call'd a King.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: {% italic: Speake, strike, redresse %}. Am I entreated

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: To speake, and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: If the redresse will follow, thou receiuest

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Thy full Petition at the hand of {% italic: Brutus %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Sir, March is wasted fifteene dayes.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: 'Tis good. Go to the Gate, some body knocks:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Since {% italic: Cassius %} first did whet me against {% italic: Cæsar %},

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: I haue not slept.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Betweene the acting of a dreadfull thing,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: And the first motion, all the {% italic: Interim %} is

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Like a {% italic: Phantasma %}, or a hideous Dreame:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The {% italic: Genius %}, and the mortall Instruments

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Are then in councell; and the state of a man,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Like to a little Kingdome, suffers then

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The nature of an Insurrection.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Sir, 'tis your Brother {% italic: Cassius %} at the Doore,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Who doth desire to see you.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Is he alone?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: No, Sir, there are moe with him.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Doe you know them?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: No, Sir, their Hats are pluckt about their Eares,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And halfe their Faces buried in their Cloakes,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: That by no meanes I may discouer them,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: By any marke of fauour.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Let 'em enter:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: They are the Faction. O Conspiracie,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Sham'st thou to shew thy dang'rous Brow by Night,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: When euills are most free? O then, by day

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Where wilt thou finde a Cauerne darke enough,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: To maske thy monstrous Visage? Seek none Conspiracie,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Hide it in Smiles, and Affabilitie:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: For if thou path thy natiue semblance on,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Not {% italic: Erebus %} it selfe were dimme enough,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: To hide thee from preuention.

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: I thinke we are too bold vpon your Rest:

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Good morrow {% italic: Brutus %}, doe we trouble you?

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: I haue beene vp this howre, awake all Night:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Know I these men, that come along with you?

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Yes, euery man of them; and no man here

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: But honors you: and euery one doth wish,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: You had but that opinion of your selfe,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Which euery Noble Roman beares of you.

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: This is {% italic: Trebonius %}.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: He is welcome hither.

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: This, {% italic: Decius Brutus %}.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: He is welcome too.

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: This, {% italic: Caska %}; this, {% italic: Cinna %}; and this, {% italic: Metellus Cymber %}.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: They are all welcome.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: What watchfull Cares doe interpose themselues

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Betwixt your Eyes, and Night?

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Shall I entreat a word?

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: Here lyes the East: doth not the Day breake

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Cin.
lines.text: O pardon, Sir, it doth; and yon grey Lines,

lines.speaker: Cin.
lines.text: That fret the Clouds, are Messengers of Day.

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: You shall confesse, that you are both deceiu'd:

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Heere, as I point my Sword, the Sunne arises,

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Which is a great way growing on the South,

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Weighing the youthfull Season of the yeare.

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Some two moneths hence, vp higher toward the North

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: He first presents his fire, and the high East

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Stands as the Capitoll, directly heere.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Giue me your hands all ouer, one by one.

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: And let vs sweare our Resolution.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: No, not an Oa: if not the Face of men,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The sufferance of our Soules, the times Abuse;

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: If these be Motiues weake, breake off betimes,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: And euery man hence, to his idle bed:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: So let high‑sighted‑Tyranny range on,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Till each man drop by Lottery. But if these

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: (As I am sure they do) beare fire enough

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: To kindle Cowards, and to steele with valour

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The melting Spirits of women. Then Countrymen,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: What neede we any spurre, but our owne cause

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: To pricke vs to redresse? What other Bond,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Then secret Romans, that haue spoke the word,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: And will not palter? And what other Oath,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Then Honesty to Honesty ingag'd,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: That this shall be, or we will fall for it.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Sweare Priests and Cowards, and men Cautelous

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Old feeble Carrions, and such suffering Soules

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: That welcome wrongs: Vnto bad causes, sweare

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Such Creatures as men doubt; but do not staine

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The euen vertue of our Enterprize,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Nor th'insuppressiue Mettle of our Spirits,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: To thinke, that or our Cause, or our Performance

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Did neede an Oath. When euery drop of blood

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: That euery Roman beares, and Nobly beares

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Is guilty of a seuerall Bastardie,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: If he do breake the smallest Particle

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Of any promise that hath past from him.

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: But what of {% italic: Cicero %}? Shall we sound him?

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: I thinke he will stand very strong with vs.

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Let vs not leaue him out.

lines.speaker: Cyn.
lines.text: No, by no meanes.

lines.speaker: Metel.
lines.text: O let vs haue him, for his Siluer haires

lines.speaker: Metel.
lines.text: Will purchase vs a good opinion:

lines.speaker: Metel.
lines.text: And buy mens voyces, to commend our deeds:

lines.speaker: Metel.
lines.text: It shall be sayd, his iudgement rul'd our hands,

lines.speaker: Metel.
lines.text: Our youths, and wildenesse, shall no whit appeare,

lines.speaker: Metel.
lines.text: But all be buried in his Grauity.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: O name him not; let vs not breake with him,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: For he will neuer follow any thing

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: That other men begin.

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: Then leaue him out.

lines.speaker: Cask.
lines.text: Indeed, he is not fit.

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: Shall no man else be toucht, but onely {% italic: Cæsar %}?

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: {% italic: Decius %} well vrg'd: I thinke it is not meet,

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: {% italic: Marke Antony %}, so well belou'd of {% italic: Cæsar %},

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: Should out‑liue {% italic: Cæsar %}, we shall finde of him

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: A shrew'd Contriuer. And you know, his meanes

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: If he improue them, may well stretch so farre

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: As to annoy vs all: which to preuent,

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: Let {% italic: Antony %} and {% italic: Cæsar %} fall together.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Our course will seeme too bloody, {% italic: Caius Cassius %},

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: To cut the Head off, and then hacke the Limbes:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Like Wrath in death, and Enuy afterwards:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: For {% italic: Antony %}, is but a Limbe of {% italic: Cæsar %}.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Let's be Sacrificers, but not Butchers {% italic: Caius %}:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: We all stand vp against the spirit of {% italic: Cæsar %},

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And in the Spirit of men, there is no blood:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: O that we then could come by {% italic: Cæsars %} Spirit,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And not dismember Cæsar! But (alas)

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: {% italic: Cæsar %} must bleed for it. And gentle Friends,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Let's kill him Boldly, but not Wrathfully:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Let's carue him, as a Dish fit for the Gods,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Not hew him as a Carkasse fit for Hounds:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And let our Hearts, as subtle Masters do,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Stirre vp their Seruants to an acte of Rage,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And after seeme to chide 'em. This shall make

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Our purpose Necessary, and not Enuious.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Which so appearing to the common eyes,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: We shall be call'd Purgers, not Murderers.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And for {% italic: Marke Antony %}, thinke not of him:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: For he can do no more then {% italic: Cæsars %} Arme,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: When {% italic: Cæsars %} head is off.

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: Yet I feare him,

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: For in the ingrafted loue he beares to {% italic: Cæsar %}.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Alas, good {% italic: Cassius %}, do not thinke of him:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: If he loue {% italic: Cæsar %}, all that he can do

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Is to himselfe; take thought, and dye for {% italic: Cæsar %},

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And that were much he should: for he is giuen

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: To sports, to wildenesse, and much company.

lines.speaker: Treb.
lines.text: There is no feare in him; let him not dye,

lines.speaker: Treb.
lines.text: For he will liue, and laugh at this heereafter.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Peace, count the Clocke.

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: The Clocke hath stricken three.

lines.speaker: Treb.
lines.text: 'Tis time to part.

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: But it is doubtfull yet,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Whether {% italic: Cæsar %} will come forth to day, or no:

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: For he is Superstitious growne of late,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Quite from the maine Opinion he held once,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Of Fantasie, of Dreames, and Ceremonies:

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: It may be, these apparant Prodigies,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: The vnaccustom'd Terror of this night,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: And the perswasion of his Augurers,

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: May hold him from the Capitoll to day.

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: Neuer feare that: If he be so resolu'd,

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: I can ore‑sway him: For he loues to heare,

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: That Vnicornes may be betray'd with Trees,

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: And Beares with Glasses, Elephants with Holes,

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: Lyons with Toyles, and men with Flatterers.

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: But, when I tell him, he hates Flatterers,

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: He sayes, he does; being then most flattered.

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: Let me worke:

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: For I can giue his humour the true bent;

lines.speaker: Decius.
lines.text: And I will bring him to the Capitoll.

lines.speaker: Cass.
lines.text: Nay, we will all of vs, be there to fetch him.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: By the eight houre, is that the vttermost?

lines.speaker: Cin.
lines.text: Be that the vttermost, and faile not then.

lines.speaker: Met.
lines.text: {% italic: Caius Ligarius %} doth beare {% italic: Cæsar %} hard,

lines.speaker: Met.
lines.text: Who rated him for speaking well of {% italic: Pompey %};

lines.speaker: Met.
lines.text: I wonder none of you haue thought of him.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Now good {% italic: Metellus %} go along by him:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: He loues me well, and I haue giuen him Reasons,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Send him but hither, and Ile fashion him.

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: The morning comes vpon's:

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: Wee'l leaue you {% italic: Brutus %},

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: And Friends disperse your selues; but all remember

lines.speaker: Cas.
lines.text: What you haue said, and shew your selues true Romans.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Good Gentlemen, looke fresh and merrily,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Let not our lookes put on our purposes,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: But beare it as our Roman Actors do,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: With vntyr'd Spirits, and formall Constancie,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And so good morrow to you euery one.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Boy: {% italic: Lucius %}: Fast asleepe? It is no matter,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Enioy the hony‑heauy‑Dew of Slumber:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Thou hast no Figures, nor no Fantasies,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Which busie care drawes, in the braines of men;

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: {% italic: Brutus %}, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: {% italic: Portia %}: What meane you? wherfore rise you now?

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: It is not for your health, thus to commit

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Your weake condition, to the raw cold morning.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Nor for yours neither. Y'haue vngently {% italic: Brutus %}

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Stole from my bed: and yesternight at Supper

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: You sodainly arose, and walk'd about,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Musing, and sighing, with your armes a‑crosse

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And when I ask'd you what the matter was,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: You star'd vpon me, with vngentle lookes.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I vrg'd you further, then you scratch'd your head,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And too impatiently stampt with your foote:

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: But with an angry wafter of your hand

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Gaue signe for me to leaue you: So I did,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Fearing to strengthen that impatience

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Which seem'd too much inkindled; and withall,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Hoping it was but an effect of Humor,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Which sometime hath his houre with euery man.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: It will not let you eate, nor talke, nor sleepe;

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And could it worke so much vpon your shape,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: As it hath much preuayl'd on your Condition,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I should not know you {% italic: Brutus %}. Deare my Lord,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Make me acquainted with your cause of greefe.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: I am not well in health, and that is all.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: {% italic: Brutus %} is wise, and were he not in health,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: He would embrace the meanes to come by it.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Why so I do: good {% italic: Portia %} go to bed.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Is {% italic: Brutus %} sicke? And is it Physicall

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: To walke vnbraced, and sucke vp the humours

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Of the danke Morning? What, is {% italic: Brutus %} sicke?

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And will he steale out of his wholsome bed

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: To dare the vile contagion of the Night?

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And tempt the Rhewmy, and vnpurged Ayre,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: To adde vnto his sicknesse? No my {% italic: Brutus %},

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: You haue some sicke Offence within your minde,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Which by the Right and Vertue of my place

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I ought to know of: And vpon my knees,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I charme you, by my once commended Beauty,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: By all your vowes of Loue, and that great Vow

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Which did incorporate and make vs one,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: That you vnfold to me, your selfe; your halfe

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Why you are heauy: and what men to night

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Haue had resort to you: for heere haue beene

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Some sixe or seuen, who did hide their faces

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Euen from darknesse.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Kneele not gentle {% italic: Portia %}.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I should not neede, if you were gentle {% italic: Brutus %}.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Within the Bond of Marriage, tell me {% italic: Brutus %},

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Is it excepted, I should know no Secrets

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: That appertaine to you? Am I your Selfe,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: But as it were in sort, or limitation?

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: To keepe with you at Meales, comfort your Bed,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And talke to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the Suburbs

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: {% italic: Portia %} is {% italic: Brutus %} Harlot, not his Wife.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: You are my true and honourable Wife,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: As deere to me, as are the ruddy droppes

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: That visit my sad heart.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: If this were true, then should I know this secret.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I graunt I am a Woman; but withall,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: A Woman that Lord {% italic: Brutus %} tooke to Wife:

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I graunt I am a Woman; but withall,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: A Woman well reputed: {% italic: Cato's %} Daughter.

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Thinke you, I am no stronger then my Sex

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Being so Father'd, and so Husbanded?

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Tell me your Counsels, I will not disclose 'em:

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: I haue made strong proofe of my Constancie,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Giuing my selfe a voluntary wound

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: Heere, in the Thigh: Can I be e that with patience,

lines.speaker: Por.
lines.text: And not my Husbands Secrets?

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: O ye Gods!

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Render me worthy of this Noble Wife.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Harke, harke, one knockes: {% italic: Portia %} go in a while,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And by and by thy bosome shall partake

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: The secrets of my Heart.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: All my engagements, I will construe to thee,

lines.text: {% italic: Antony %},

lines.text: Clowds, Dewes, and Dangers come; our deeds are done:

lines.speaker: Titin.
lines.text: Mistrust of my successe hath done this deed.

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Mistrust of good successe hath done this deed.

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: O hatefull Error, Melancholies Childe:

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Why do'st thou shew to the apt thoughts of men

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: The things that are not? O Error soone conceyu'd,

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Thou neuer com'st vnto a happy byrth,

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: But kil'st the Mother that engendred thee.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: What {% italic: Pindarus? %} Where art thou {% italic: Pindarus? %}

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Seeke him {% italic: Titinius %}, whilst I go to meet

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: The Noble {% italic: Brutus %}, thrusting this report

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Into his eares; I may say thrusting it:

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: For piercing Steele, and Darts inuenomed,

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Shall be as welcome to the eares of {% italic: Brutus %},

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: As tydings of this sight.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Hye you {% italic: Messala %},

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And I will seeke for {% italic: Pindarus %} the while:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Why did'st thou send me forth braue {% italic: Cassius %}?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Did I not meet thy Friends, and did not they

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Put on my Browes this wreath of Victorie,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And bid me giue it thee? Did'st thou not heare their. ( showts?

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Alas, thou hast misconstrued euery thing.

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: But hold thee, take this Garland on thy Brow,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Thy {% italic: Brutus %} bid me giue it thee, and I

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Will do his bidding. {% italic: Brutus %}, come apace,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: And see how I regarded {% italic: Caius Cassius %}:

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: By your leaue Gods: This is a Romans part,

lines.speaker: Tit.
lines.text: Come {% italic: Cassius %} Sword, and finde {% italic: Titinius %} hart.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Where, where {% italic: Messala %}, doth his body lye?

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: Loe yonder, and {% italic: Titinius %} mourning it.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: {% italic: Titinius %} face is vpward.

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: He is slaine.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: O {% italic: Iulius CÆsar %}, thou art mighty yet,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Thy Spirit walkes abroad, and turnes our Swords

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: In our owne proper Entrailes.

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: Braue {% italic: Titinius %},

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: Looke where he haue not crown'd dead {% italic: Cassius %}.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Are yet two Romans liuing such as these?

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: The last of all the Romans, far thee well:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: It is impossible, that euer Rome

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Should breed thy fellow. Friends I owe mo teares

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: To this dead man, then you shall see me pay.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: I shall finde time, {% italic: Cassius %}: I shall finde time.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Come therefore, and to {% italic: Tharsus %} send his body,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: His Funerals shall not be in our Campe,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Least it discomfort vs. {% italic: Lucillius %} come,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: And come yong {% italic: Cato %}, let vs to the Field,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: {% italic: Labio %} and {% italic: Flauio %} set our Battailes on:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: 'Tis three a clocke, and Romans yet ere night,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: We shall try Fortune in a second fight.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Yet Country‑men: O yet, hold vp your heads.

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: What Bastard doth not? Who will go with me?

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: I will proclaime my name about the Field.

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: I am the Sonne of {% italic: Marcus Cato %}, hoe.

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: A Foe to Tyrants, and my Countries Friend.

lines.speaker: Cato.
lines.text: I am the Sonne of {% italic: Marcus Cato %}, hoe.
And I am {% italic: Brutus %}, {% italic: Marcus Brutus %}, I,
{% italic: Brutus %} my Countries Friend: Know me for {% italic: Brutus %}.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: O yong and Noble {% italic: Cato %}, art thou downe?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Why now thou dyest, as brauely as {% italic: Titinius %},

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And may'st be honour'd, being {% italic: Cato %} 's Sonne.

lines.speaker: Sold.
lines.text: Yeeld, or thou dyest.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Onely I yeeld to dye:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: There is so much, that thou wilt kill me straight:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Kill {% italic: Brutus %}, and be honour'd in his death.

lines.speaker: Sold.
lines.text: We must not: a Noble Prisoner.

lines.speaker: 2. Sold.
lines.text: Roome hoe: tell {% italic: Antony %}, {% italic: Brutus %} is tane.

lines.speaker: 1. Sold.
lines.text: Ile tell thee newes. Heere comes the Generall,

lines.speaker: 1. Sold.
lines.text: {% italic: Brutus %} is tane, {% italic: Brutus %} is tane my Lord.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Where is hee?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Safe {% italic: Antony %}, {% italic: Brutus %} is safe enough:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: I dare assure thee, that no Enemy

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Shall euer take aliue the Noble {% italic: Brutus %}:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: The Gods defend him from so great a shame,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: When you do finde him, or aliue, or dead,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: He will be found like {% italic: Brutus %}, like himselfe.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: This is not {% italic: Brutus %} friend, but I assure you,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: A prize no lesse in worth; keepe this man safe,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Giue him all kindnesse. I had rather haue

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Such men my Friends, then Enemies. Go on,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And see where {% italic: Brutus %} be aliue or dead,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And bring vs word, vnto {% italic: Octauius %} Tent:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: How euery thing is chanc'd.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Come poore remaines of friends, rest on this

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: {% italic: Statillius %} shew'd the Torch‑light, but my Lord

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: He came not backe: he is or tane, or slaine.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Sit thee downe, {% italic: Clitus %}: slaying is the word,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: It is a deed in fashion. Hearke thee, {% italic: Clitus %}.

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: What I, my Lord? No, not for all the World.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Peace then, no words.

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: Ile rather kill my selfe.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Hearke thee, {% italic: Dardanius %}.

lines.speaker: Dard.
lines.text: Shall I doe such a deed?

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: O {% italic: Dardanius %}.

lines.speaker: Dard.
lines.text: O {% italic: Clitus %}

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: What ill request did {% italic: Brutus %} make to thee?

lines.speaker: Dard.
lines.text: To kill him, {% italic: Clitus: %} looke he meditates.

lines.speaker: Clit.
lines.text: Now is that Noble Vessell full of griefe, That it runnes ouer euen at his eyes

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Come hither, good {% italic: Volumnius %}, list a word.

lines.speaker: Volum.
lines.text: What sayes my Lord?

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Why this, {% italic: Volumnius %}

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: The Ghost of {% italic: CÆsar %} hath appear'd to me

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Two seuerall times by Night: at Sardis, once;

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: And this last Night, here in Philippi fields:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: I know my houre is come.

lines.speaker: Volum.
lines.text: Not so, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Nay, I am sure it is, {% italic: Volumnius %}.

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Thou seest the World, {% italic: Volumnius %}, how it goes,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Our Enemies haue beat vs to the Pit:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: It is more worthy, to leape in our selues,

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Then tarry till they push vs. Good {% italic: Volumnius %},

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Thou know'st, that we two went to Schoole together:

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Euen for that our loue of old, I prethee

lines.speaker: Brut.
lines.text: Hold thou my Sword Hilts, whilest I runne on it.

lines.speaker: Vol.
lines.text: That's not an Office for a friend, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Cly.
lines.text: Fly, flye my Lord, there is no tarrying heere.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Farewell to you, and you, and {% italic: Volumnius %}.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: {% italic: Strato %}, thou hast bin all this while asleepe:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Farewell to thee, to {% italic: Strato %}, Countrymen:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: My heart doth ioy, that yet in all my life,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: I found no man, but he was true to me.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: I shall haue glory by this loosing day

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: More then {% italic: Octauius %}, and {% italic: Marke Antony %},

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: By this vile Conquest shall attaine vnto.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: So fare you well at once, for {% italic: Brutus %} tongue

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Hath almost ended his liues History:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Night hangs vpon mine eyes, my Bones would rest,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: That haue but labour'd, to attaine this houre.

lines.speaker: Cly.
lines.text: Fly my Lord, flye.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Hence: I will follow:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: I prythee {% italic: Strato %}, stay thou by thy Lord,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Thou art a Fellow of a good respect:

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Thy life hath had some smatch of Honor in it,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Hold then my Sword, and turne away thy face,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: While I do run vpon it. Wilt thou {% italic: Strato %}?

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: Giue me your hand first. Fare you wel my Lord.

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: Farewell good {% italic: Strato %}. ⸺ {% italic: CÆsar %}, now be still,

lines.speaker: Bru.
lines.text: I kill'd not thee with halfe so good a will.

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: What man is that?

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: My Masters man. {% italic: Strato %}, where is thy Master?

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: Free from the Bondage you are in {% italic: Messala %},

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: The Conquerors can but make a fire of him:

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: For {% italic: Brutus %} onely ouercame himselfe,

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: And no man else hath Honor by his death.

lines.speaker: Lucil.
lines.text: So {% italic: Brutus %} should be found. I thank thee {% italic: Brutus %}

lines.speaker: Lucil.
lines.text: That thou hast prou'd {% italic: Lucillius %} saying true.

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: All that seru'd {% italic: Brutus %}, I will entertaine them.

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: I, if {% italic: Messala %} will preferre me to you.

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: Do so, good {% italic: Messala %}.

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: How dyed my Master {% italic: Strato %}?

lines.speaker: Stra.
lines.text: I held the Sword, and he did run on it.

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: {% italic: Octauius %}, then take him to follow thee,

lines.speaker: Messa.
lines.text: That did the latest seruice to my Master.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: This was the Noblest Roman of them all:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: All the Conspirators saue onely hee,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Did that they did, in enuy of great {% italic: Cæsar %}:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: He, onely in a generall honest thought,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And common good to all, made one of them.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: His life was gentle, and the Elements

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: So mixt in him, that Nature might stand vp,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And say to all the world; This was a man.

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: According to his Vertue, let vs vse him

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: Withall Respect, and Rites of Buriall.

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: Within my Tent his bones to night shall ly,

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: Most like a Souldier ordered Honourably:

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: So call the Field to rest, and let's away,

lines.speaker: Octa.
lines.text: To part the glories of this happy day.
